POR.DRECONTENT:
Vertex operator algebra theory is a relatively new field of mathematics which grew out of work done in both theoretical physics and mathematics. It has been shown to have deep applications and roots within both mathematics and physics and has led to the solution of various problems in number theory, combinatorics, algebra, string theory, and quantum field theory.  The focus of the current project is to study twisted representations of vertex operator algebras, and more importantly, to construct the first examples of a certain type of twisted module.  The importance of studying twisted representations is twofold. First, the study and construction of twisted representations has led to the solution of many important mathematical problems in the fields of mathematics described above. Second, studying twisted representations of vertex operator algebras in mathematics is known to be equivalent to studying orbifold theories in theoretical physics, which describe various symmetries involved in particle physics. In particular, any problem in orbifold theory can be reformulated to an equivalent problem about twisted representations of a vertex operator algebra, and vice-versa.

The current project is a direct generalization of past work done by the principal investigator (PI), and involves the construction of generalized twisted representations of vertex operator algebras.  The project was successful in that it led to the construction of many examples of generalized twisted representations based on affine Lie algebras, and direct computation of certain twisted vertex operators. One of the important problems here was to discover twisted vertex operators with logarithm terms in them, something which had not appeared in past study of twisted representations. A second important problem was to determine if certain horizontal gradings appeared in these generalized twisted representations. The PI showed that in the affine Lie algebra case, the answer to both questions is in the affirmative, and constructed various examples of generalized twisted representations, both with and without logarithm terms appearing and both with and without horizontal gradings. The PI proved that, in some cases, the appearance of both phenomena simultaneously was impossible, and also constructed examples where both phenomena did occur simultaneously. Using these constructions, the PI was able to study the properties of the constructed representations, including investigating their relations to the tensor product theory of vertex operator algebras. The PI is currently investigating certain finiteness properties of the constructed generalized twisted representations, as well as generalized twisted representations in general. This ongoing work will lead to greater insights in and constructions of particular orbifold theories, and even logarithmic conformal field theories, in theoretical physics.
